Description: Terracotta male fecundity figure. A squatting male figure, his legs bent double and his feet widely splayed, reaching forward to grasp the root of his huge phallus with both hands. He is naked and has a distended stomach; there may be an amulet on his chest. His features are slightly grotesque and he is bald but for a band of hair encircling his head except for his brow. Summary modelling at the rear, with an applied suspension-lug between the shoulders. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt with a brown surface. Traces of a white dressing on the front.
Curator's comments: Previously interpreted as a female figure giving birth.
BM Terracotta IV Comparandum. Near: Fischer 1994: no. 525, dated second half of second century to third century ad. Bibliog. Fischer 1994: 250, no. 525.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3145)
